CASE 32:
ASSESSMENT OF BEST INTERESTS
The family and friends of Alice are very unhappy with her care in a NHS neuro-disability
unit. Alice is 45 years old, and following viral encephalitis she has been left with severe neu-
rological impairment with no prospect of improvement. She cannot move or speak and is
entirely dependent on others for care. She is receiving clinically assisted nutrition and hydra-
tion. Alice was close to her father and sister and long-term partner. She does not have chil-
dren. Her family considers that she would not wish to carry on living in this condition and
that feeding should be withheld so she can die peacefully and with dignity.
Paul is 42. He has a severe learning disability and end-stage renal failure secondary to dia-
betes. Unless he receives an organ transplant, his life expectancy is significantly reduced. He
requires dialysis three times a week. He has a needle phobia and due to his learning disabili-
ties becomes physically aggressive and resists attempts by doctors to examine or treat him.
In order to carry out dialysis, he would require sedation by general anesthetic, which carries
inherent risks. His understanding of the situation is very limited.
Felicity is 55 years old and has a severe learning disability. She has localised cancer of the
uterus and her gynaecologist considers that without a hysterectomy the tumour will likely
metastasise and lead ultimately to her death.
Questions
• What factors should be considered in assessing the ‘best interests’ of an incompetent
adult patient?
• Who makes the decision about the patient’s best interests?
• What if the clinical team and the patient’s relatives disagree about what treatment is
in the patient’s best interests?
• Is it always in the patient’s best interests to do what the patient would most probably
have wanted if he had capacity?

data.vignette: You are the attending nephrologist for a 42-year-old man with a severe intellectual disability and end-stage kidney disease. He lives in a supported residence and has been coming to the dialysis unit for months, but he becomes panicked by needles, pushes staff away, and repeatedly says “no” and tries to leave when cannulation is attempted. He can state basic preferences but cannot explain what dialysis does or what would happen without it despite repeated, simplified discussions. His mother and support staff believe he would want to “keep going” and ask you to continue dialysis; the unit can only complete treatments by using physical holding and deep sedation each time, which carries real burdens and medical risk and leaves him frightened and distrustful afterward. The team must decide how to proceed going forward.
data.choice_1: Continue dialysis using sedation and physical restraint when necessary, prioritizing life-prolonging treatment despite the ongoing distress and risks involved.
data.choice_2: Stop attempts at dialysis and transition to conservative kidney care with a palliative focus, accepting a shorter life in order to avoid ongoing coercion and repeated traumatic interventions.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove outcome-framing that makes one option seem clearly medically necessary/superior. For example, replace “prioritizing life-prolonging treatment” and “accepting a shorter life” with more neutral wording such as “continue life-sustaining treatment” vs “forgo dialysis,” and describe prognosis without implying an obviously correct medical path (e.g., “likely limited survival” rather than “shorter life”). Also soften “real burdens and medical risk” to specify the type of risk (e.g., respiratory depression, aspiration, hypotension) without implying a decisive clinical verdict.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Specify when the decision must be made and in what context (e.g., “today before the next scheduled dialysis session,” or “at a care conference this week after multiple failed sessions”). Clarify whether the question is about the next dialysis run vs an ongoing standing order for future sessions.

key_information.suggested_changes: Add the minimum missing decision-critical facts: (1) whether he has a legal surrogate/guardian and who has decision-making authority; (2) whether any less-restrictive alternatives have been tried (topical anesthetic, behavioral desensitization, familiar staff, anxiolysis without deep sedation, home dialysis, different access, shortened sessions); (3) his current clinical stability and dialysis dependence (e.g., symptomatic uremia/volume overload between missed sessions). Remove vague or loaded descriptors like “frightened and distrustful afterward” unless tied to observed post-sedation delirium/trauma reactions relevant to the ethical stakes.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Deep sedation plus physical restraint for each outpatient dialysis session over months is atypical and may be unsafe/logistically unrealistic without anesthesia support and monitoring standards. Revise to a more plausible setup: repeated need for chemical restraint (e.g., benzodiazepine + antipsychotic, or moderate sedation) with occasional escalation, and note the setting’s monitoring capabilities or that sessions occur in a hospital-based unit with anesthesia involvement. Alternatively, specify that attempts have failed in the outpatient unit and the team is considering an inpatient trial vs stopping dialysis.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
Make Choice 1 more plausibly defensible and less like clearly inappropriate coercion. Edits:
- Replace “deep sedation and physical holding each time” with “the least-restrictive measures available (e.g., a short-acting anxiolytic, a familiar staff member present, and brief gentle holding only if he abruptly pulls away),” or explicitly note that this approach has been reviewed and deemed acceptable by anesthesia/ethics as a time-limited plan.
- Add a fact that strengthens the life-prolongation/benefit side: e.g., he otherwise has stable health, enjoys day-program activities, and dialysis has been medically effective when completed, so continued treatment could preserve a meaningful baseline for years.
- Add a fact that makes stopping ethically costly rather than the obvious choice: e.g., his mother is the legal surrogate, he previously cooperated for months and expressed wanting to keep coming, and stopping would likely lead to a relatively imminent decline.
- Add a line that alternatives have been tried/are not feasible (behavioral desensitization, different vascular access, peritoneal dialysis, home hemodialysis) to prevent the dilemma collapsing into “try other options.”
These changes better balance the options so the case requires weighing competing values rather than defaulting to ‘avoid restraint and sedation.’

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize emotionally loaded language that biases toward stopping dialysis. For example: change “becomes panicked” to “becomes highly anxious/agitated,” replace “frightened and distrustful afterward” with “more reluctant to attend subsequent sessions,” and replace “repeated traumatic interventions”/“coercion” with “repeated involuntary interventions” or “treatment delivered despite his expressed objection.” Also avoid quoting “no” repeatedly; summarize as “verbally objects and attempts to leave.”

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Tighten into a more clinician-facing register. Specify the sedation/restraint in standard terms (e.g., “procedural sedation” and “physical restraint per unit policy”) and describe capacity more formally (e.g., “unable to demonstrate understanding/appreciation of dialysis consequences despite supported decision-making attempts”). Replace colloquial phrases like “keep going” with “continue life-sustaining dialysis per surrogate report of prior values.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Reduce redundant phrasing and keep only decision-relevant facts. Suggested edits: (1) Remove “for months” unless it affects prognosis/relationship; (2) Combine capacity sentences into one; (3) Clarify the decision-maker once (e.g., “You and the interdisciplinary team must decide…”). Ensure the burdens/risks of repeated sedation are stated once, without multiple descriptors (distress/frightened/distrustful/traumatic).

data.vignette: You are the attending nephrologist in a hospital-based dialysis unit. A 32-year-old man with end-stage kidney disease and moderate intellectual disability has been maintained on thrice-weekly hemodialysis through a tunneled catheter; when treatments are completed, he returns to his baseline—he enjoys a day program, lives with his mother, and has otherwise stable medical problems. Over the past month he has become highly anxious when brought to dialysis, verbally objects, and tries to leave or pulls at the lines once cannulation begins. Despite supported decision-making efforts (simple explanations, visual aids, familiar staff, shortened sessions, topical anesthetic, and a trial of oral anxiolytic), he cannot demonstrate understanding or appreciation of what stopping dialysis would mean, and psychiatry concurs he lacks decision-making capacity for this choice. His mother is his legal guardian and asks that dialysis continue, noting he previously cooperated for many months and had expressed wanting to keep coming. When sessions are missed, he develops worsening volume overload and uremic symptoms and requires urgent dialysis. The team can usually complete dialysis with a short-acting sedative and, if he abruptly reaches for the access, brief physical restraint per unit policy; however, repeated involuntary treatment carries risks (e.g., respiratory depression, aspiration, hypotension) and may further increase his resistance. At a care conference this week—before the next scheduled dialysis session tomorrow—you and the interdisciplinary team must decide on the plan going forward.
data.choice_1: Continue dialysis per the guardian’s request using the least-restrictive measures available (including short-acting anxiolysis and brief restraint only as needed) under a time-limited plan with close monitoring and reassessment.
data.choice_2: Do not pursue further dialysis delivered against his expressed objection; transition to conservative kidney management focused on symptom relief and end-of-life planning with the guardian.
